awd_titl_txt: STTR Phase I:  Emulating Biological Actuation
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this project includes development of robust control algorithms for a robotic, foot-ankle prosthesis based on the winding filament hypothesis, a transformative new idea about how muscles contract. The winding filament hypothesis is uniquely able to account for properties of muscles that allow instantaneous and automatic adaptation of stiffness to unexpected changes in load. In the U.S. today, 1.6 -1.8 million persons live with loss of a limb. Despite the success of the latest technological improvements, significant challenges remain in development of robotic prostheses and other assistive devices. No devices available on the market today can reproduce normal walking movements under variable conditions (e.g., sand or other compliant substrates, stairs, steep ramps). These limitations affect quality of life by limiting participation in activities of daily life, including maintenance of physical fitness. Benefits of a robust powered prosthesis include increased versatility from level walking at a range of speeds, to stairs, ramps and varied terrain. The technology could also be extended to ankle orthoses for people whose mobility is limited by stroke, diabetes, or other conditions of disease and aging. In addition, development of bio-inspired control algorithms will enhance the scientific and technological understanding of muscle-like actuation.

This Small Business Technology Transfer Research (STTR) Phase I project involves collaboration between a leading provider of robotic foot-ankle prostheses for persons with a lower limb amputation, and developers of the winding filament hypothesis, a transformative new idea about how muscles contract. The goal of the project is to demonstrate the technical and commercial feasibility of developing a robust control algorithm for a robotic prosthesis, based on the winding filament hypothesis. A powered, foot-ankle prosthesis will be modified to accommodate the bio-inspired control algorithms, the algorithms will be modified to account for prosthesis properties, and performance will be optimized for a broad range of terrains and conditions, including ramps, stairs and compliant surfaces. If the winding filament hypothesis algorithm can outperform the stock prosthesis controller in the range of conditions under which it emulates normal walking, this would provide proof-of-concept that a robust prosthesis controller is technically and commercially feasible. Robust control represents a disruptive market advance not only for prosthesis technology, but also for orthotic devices. A more versatile prosthesis would improve the quality of life for millions of Americans with limb loss.

por.por_cntn:
The latest robotic prosthetic devices function well during level walking at variable cadence. However, no prosthetic devices available on the market today can reproduce normal walking under more variable conditions. In contrast, muscles are the ultimate evolved biological machines that perform well under a wide range of conditions. Until recently, the mechanisms that muscles use to achieve this robust performance were largely unknown. With previous funding from NSF, researchers at Northern Arizona University developed a “winding filament” hypothesis (WFH) for muscle contraction, which proposes that the actin thin filaments in a muscle sarcomere act like a pulley, and that the cross-bridges wind the giant titin protein on this pulley during active muscle contraction. The hypothesis suggests that the key to emulating muscle function is to place a moveable pulley between a motor and a spring, so that the spring is simultaneously in series and in parallel with the motor. Simulations demonstrate that a constitutive model based on the winding filament hypothesis accurately predicts the force output of muscles in response to applied forces.

This STTR Phase I project further developed and implemented the WFH model on a BionX BiOM ankle prosthesis, and conducted walking studies with human subjects. The results unequivocally demonstrate that the WFH-algorithm can produce normal walking at variable speed and over variable terrain with no change in activation or other parameters, and without requiring any information about the user’s intended activity. It demonstrates proof of concept, not only that the winding filament muscle model is superior to previous muscle models, including the ubiquitous Hill-type muscle models, but also that biologically inspired muscle models that account for muscle intrinsic properties can be useful for controlling wearable robotic devices. The torque adaptation that is observed when a user transitions from one activity to another, for example from level walking to stair ascent, is achieved by including only the effects of external forces applied to the virtual muscles at the ankle joint. The transition includes no change in muscle activation, which represents voluntary control. By demonstrating the sufficiency of muscle intrinsic properties for control of all-terrain walking, the results suggest how these properties may contribute to human motor control.

Development of the bio-inspired control algorithms will enhance the scientific and technological understanding of muscle-like actuation. Although there have been many attempts to develop neuromuscular control algorithms for wearable robotic devices, our algorithms are the first to demonstrate distinct advantages over a purely engineering-based approach. The success of our algorithm demonstrates significant improvement in our understanding of force production by muscle. Our preliminary data demonstrate that the WFH-algorithm can produce normal ankle torques during stair ascent without requiring changes to any model parameters including muscle activation. The results imply that the torques produced by human muscles during natural movements may depend as much on intrinsic muscle properties (pre-flexes) as on feed-forward or feedback control of muscle activation by the nervous system. The “winding filament hypothesis” captures the ability of muscle to change its stiffness in response to applied forces without requiring feedback from the nervous system.

The new control algorithm for wearable robotic devices increases versatility from level walking at a range of speeds, to stairs, ramps and varied terrain, which can significantly affect the wearers’ quality of life by increasing participation in activities of daily life, including maintenance of physical fitness. The technology has the potential to improve the health and well-being of millions of persons with an amputation, and could also be extended to ankle orthoses for people whose mobility is limited by stroke, diabetes, or other conditions of disease and aging.
